The dry reforming of methane plays a vital role in carbon recycling. However, despite their high activity, Ni catalysts are susceptible to deactivation caused by the deposition of carbon. Co-doped Ni catalysts can address this issue, but the doping ratio has obvious effect on the activity. In this study, we utilized density functional theory calculations and microkinetic model simulations to gain insight into how Co doping affects both carbon deposition resistance and Ni catalytic activity. By analyzing the reaction mechanism, we discovered that the concentration of surface O* significantly influences the deactivation of carbon deposition on the surface of Ni-based catalysts. An appropriate concentration of O* can reduce the occupation of CC* sites, while excessive O* results in surface poisoning and reduced H2 production rates. We propose that the anti-carbon deposition performance of Ni catalysts can be improved by modulating the CH4/CO2 inlet ratio appropriately. Our findings provide valuable guidance for rational design of effective DRM catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Co-doped Ni catalysts Dry reforming of methane Microkinetic modeling Anti-carbon deposition Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Developing effective ways of chemical energy storage is an available means to realize net emissions from the carbon cycle in energy-intensive industries [1–4]. One promising approach to address the issue of greenhouse gases is through the use of the catalytic dry reforming of methane (DRM) reaction [5,6], which can effectively convert two gases (CH4 and CO2) into valuable industrial synthesis [7]. In recent years, this technology has received increasing attention for achieving zero emissions and developing solutions for carbon neutralization, hydrogen utilization, and chemical energy storage [8,9]. However, the catalyst efficiency of DRM reactions tends to decrease or deactivate over time due to carbon deposition and catalyst sintering, which limits its commercial development. While noble metal catalysts are less sensitive to carbon formation, Ni catalysts are still preferred for dry methane reformation due to their significantly lower cost [10,11]. Currently, many studies have focused on improving the deactivation of Ni catalysts using bimetallic catalysts [12,13]. Although common low-cost bimetallic catalysts such as Ni/Cu have shown good performance in carbon removal, the lower Tamman temperature makes Cu more prone to sintering during the reaction temperature [14,15]. In contrast, modified Ni catalysts with cobalt (Co) show great promise in terms of sintering and high activity [16,17]. Researchers have demonstrated that doping proportions of Co between Ni-Ni atoms can improve the stability, activity, and resistance to carbon deposition of the catalyst in a DRM reaction. According to Huang et al. [18], the content of Ni affects the activity of CH4 cracking, while the content of Co affects the oxidation reaction on the surface. Meanwhile, some experiments reveal that variations in the Co loading can impact the catalytic deactivation of Ni-based bimetallic catalysts, either through oxidation or carbon deposition [19,20]. In particular, Bian et al. [21] find that catalysts with Ni/Co ratios of 4/1, and 3/1 exhibited good activity and stability, while when Ni/Co is greater than 1, carbon deposition would deactivate the catalysts. Similarly, Alrafei et al. [22] demonstrat that the catalyst of Ni/Co = 1 on Al2O3 display better activity than Ni at temperatures of 350°, while maintaining remarkable stability over a 200 h run. In contrast, Fakeeha et al. [23]. conduct tests on catalysts with a Ni/Co ratio of 1/3 supported on Pd+Al2O3 and make an interesting observation. They find that T due to the strong interaction between the metal and the support, the catalyst has fewer exposed active sites, resulting in lower catalytic activity and significant carbon accumulation. In view of the experimental conclusions, although the dispersion of the support affects the catalytic activity, the support does not participate in the reaction, therefore, it is an urgent need to gain a comprehensive understanding of the mechanism behind Co doping in Ni catalysts and its influence on reactivity and stability. Furthermore, the formation of carbon deposits is mainly due to the methane decomposition reaction, which has a great influence on reaction conditions [24,25]. At reaction temperatures, the concentration of oxygen on the Ni surface is reduced with the increase in temperature, which limits the oxidation of carbon and promotes the formation of carbon nuclei on the surface [26]. The experiment by Lee et al. [27] shows a 5% NiCo catalyst load on Al2O3 at 550°exhibit higher conversion rates than a Ni catalyst after 62 h, which mainly attribute to the impact of O migration rates. Furthermore, the conversion of CO2 also plays a significant role in influencing the deposition of carbonaceous species. X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) measurements have verified that the Co catalyst is susceptible to oxidation at the DRM reaction temperature [28]. Similarly, X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) studies reveal that Co increases the capacity of CO2 adsorption, which eventually leads to an increase in the surface coverage of oxygen concentration [29]. Typically, the intake ratio of CH4 to CO2 is maintained at an equimolar proportion. Xiao et al. discover that by adjusting the intake ratio of CH4 to CO2 to 1:3, using a Ni catalyst encapsulation within ZSM-5, and operating at a reaction temperature of 600 °C, they observe no carbon deposition for over 50 h [30]. However, it is still unknown whether carbon deposition is influenced by changes in the migration rate of oxygen or by the encapsulated Ni catalyst. Although there have been reports on the behavior of oxygen in DRM reactions through DFT and microkinetic studies, there is still a lack of reports regarding the effects of changing the CO2 ratio. The aim of this study is to gain a better understanding of how Ni/Co catalysts behave in DRM reactions under different conditions. We investigate the impact of competitive pathways and reaction conditions on catalytic activity and selectivity by using energy span and microkinetic analysis, along with first-principles calculations. To represent various types of Ni/Co catalysts, we simulate the surfaces of Ni(111), Co(111), Ni3Co(111), and NiCo3(111). The energy span model helps evaluate the efficiency of catalytic cycles, and through first-principles calculations, we can determine the rate-determining state with the highest turnover frequency (TOF) by considering both entropy and enthalpy contributions. Additionally, we develop a microkinetic model to examine competitive approaches and investigate how realistic time scales and temperatures are affected by factors such as kinetic limitations, surface poisoning, and competitive reactions that hinder achieving the maximum TOF. Furthermore, we provide insights into the deactivation mechanism of Ni/Co catalysts in DRM reactions on different surfaces, and propose potential strategies for designing active and stable Ni catalysts for use in future industrial applications. 2 Method 2.1 Computation details All calculations are performed using the Cambridge Sequential Total Energy Package (CASTEP) code [31]. Ultrasoft pseudopotentials [32] with a cutoff energy extended to 400 eV are used to describe the electron-ion interaction. We employ the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional theory with generalized gradient approximation (GGA) [33] for exchange-correlation energies, which is widely used in heterogeneous catalysis [34,35]. The BFGS conjugate gradient algorithm [36] is used to optimize all adsorption geometries. Spin polarization effects are taken into account for all configurations involving ferromagnetic elements (Ni and Co), with a smearing width [37] of 0.1 eV/Å. The transition state (TS) is obtained using the LST/QST method [38]. Energy convergence criteria of less than 10–5 eV/Å are employed for geometry optimization, while 10–7 eV/Å is used for transition state search, and force convergence of 0.03 eV/Å to ensure high accuracy. In this work, we construct Ni(111), Co(111), and NiCo3(111) surfaces and compare with our previous work on Ni3Co(111) catalyst to investigate the mechanism of Co doping [39]. A four layers slab of a p(4 × 4) supercell with a 15 Å vacuum is used to accommodate the adsorption and the reaction immediately adsorbates. The bottom two layers are fixed to accommodate surface relaxation. We sample the catalyst surface Brillouin zone of 3 × 3 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-grid [40]. The chemical potentials (Δμ) of all adsorbates and transition species are calculated in the following Eq. (1). (1) Δ μ = U i − ∑ j ( n j R j ) where Ui is the total energy of the species i. The nj is the number of atomic species nj and Rj is the reference energy of that atomic species. In this work all species in the DRM reaction is relative to carbon (C) in methane (CH4), oxygen (O) in H2O, and hydrogen (H) in molecular hydrogen (H2), more details as shown in Supporting Information (Part 1). Specifically, the adsorbate is simulated in a 20 Å × 20 Å × 20 Å cube, and spin polarization is considered. The van der Waals correction through DFT-D3 [41] is applied to account for the weakly adsorbed species, CH4 and CO2. 2.2 Energy span calculation The energy span is used to describe theoretical efficiency of the catalytic cycles using free energy state derived from foregoing calculations [42,43]. For gaseous species and tightly adsorbed species the thermodynamics corrections are based on ideal gas approximation and harmonic approximation, respectively. The free energy data of Ni3Co is based on our previous work [39]. The turnover frequency (TOF) through energy span model is calculated as follows: (2) TOF = k B T h e − Δ G / R T − 1 ∑ e ( G T − G I − δ G ) / k B T Where kB was the Boltzmann constant, h was the Planck constant, T was the temperature, ΔG, GT , and GI were the Gibbs free energy of reaction, turnover-determining transition states (TDTS) and turnover-determining intermediate states (TDI), respectively. The degree of TOF is used to characterize the degree of TOF control of transition state [44], which has been proved as a useful tool in large energy landscape difference across catalytic cycles, was calculated as follows: (3) X i = ∑ I e ( G T − G I − δ G ) ∑ T I e ( G T − G I − δ G ) Where I and T are represented intermediate state and transition state, respectively. The higher value indicated the greater contribution of transition state on the TOF. 2.3 Microkinetic model simulation details A mean-field microkinetic model is carried out by using the PyCatKin python code [45], which describes complex elementary steps occurring on a catalyst surface in heterogeneous [46]. The complexes integrators are solved using solve_ivp steady-state solver [47], with the absolute and relative tolerance are 10e-6 and 10e-8, respectively. In our study, we utilize a model based on a continuously stirred tank reactor (CSTR) [48], where the mixture is assumed to be uniform throughout the reactor. More details are in the supporting information. We consider the reaction rate constants for all steps to follow the Arrhenius equation, with the pre-factor determined using the transition state theory. The simulation temperature is set to 800–1300 K, with the total pressure of 1 bar. All simulation results that have reached steady state are adopted. In order to ensure the correctness of our simulation, all simulation data refer to the experimental conditions [30]. The TOF of simulation data are in good agreement with the experimental, as shown in Fig. S1. This means the method adopted is reasonable. The values of all TOF function with temperature from the last time node. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Adsorption energy and linear scaling relation This study aims to investigate the catalytic activity mechanism of Co doping on the DRM reaction and the anti-coking performance of Ni by analyzing the surfaces of Ni(111), Co(111), Ni3Co(111), and NiCo3(111). Fig. 1 illustrates the structures with lattice parameters, indicating that pure metal bond lengths, such as Ni-Ni and Co-Co, undergo minimal changes in the horizontal direction after Co doping. However, in the inclined direction, the bond length of Ni-Ni on the Ni3Co(111) surface elongates from 2.497 to 2.521 Å, while the bond length of Co-Co on the NiCo3(111) surface contracts from 2.540 to 2.481 Å. The expansion of the lattice strain is expected to elevate the d-band center of the metal, leading to an increase in the interaction between the adsorbates and the catalyst surface. Therefore, the d-band center on the metal surface will be arranged in order of Ni, Ni3Co(111), NiCo3(111), and Co(111), which is consistent with our previous findings [39]. The most stable structures of intermediates on Ni(111), Co(111), Ni3Co(111), and NiCo3(111) are represented in Figs. S2–5, and corresponding relative formation energies are listed in Table S2. The results show that the adsorbates exhibited similar adsorption positions on each surface, but with varying adsorption energies. The adsorption energy is found to have a linear relationship with the amount of Co doping on the Ni surface, which is established through linear scaling relations based on the adsorption energy of C* and O* on each surface, as represented in Fig. 2 . This implies that adjusting the ratio of Ni/Co can influence the adsorption stability of adsorbates and ultimately affect the DRM reaction process. Noticeably, the weakly adsorbed species (CH4 and CO2) on the surface are not considered. Moreover, in order to understand the relationship between relative forming energy and adsorption energy, the value of O* on each surface is analyzed, as shown in Fig. 2i. It is noted that the slope deviations are consistent, suggesting that the two adsorption energies exhibit a similar trend. Therefore, for an adsorbate, the lower the formation energy, the higher the adsorption energy on the surface. As depicted in Fig. 2, the adsorbates formation energy exhibits linear scaling behavior across various Ni/Co surface ratios. Furthermore, Ni3Co(111) exhibits a similar value to Ni(111), whereas NiCo3(111) aligns more closely with Co(111). In addition, the slope is positive for the adsorption of CH3*, CH2*, CC*, and OH*, respectively. The slope is negative for CH*, CHO*, CO*, and H*, respectively. These suggesting that the synergistic effect of Ni/Co has a combined influence on the adsorption of reactant species. Specifically, Co weakens the adsorption energy of all CHx species (with a slope close to zero on CH), while increasing the adsorption energy of oxidised forms of carbon. We further analyze the linear relationship of bond strength on each surface by electronic structure, and the representative CO* is selected for analysis. As shown in Fig. 3 , Mülliken electron transfer shows that for CO*, the gain of electrons from the surface by adsorbate decreases in turn according to the Ni(111), Ni3Co(111), NiCo3(111), and Co(111) surfaces, respectively. The relationship between electron transfer and binding strength is directly proportional, meaning that more electrons transferred to the adsorbed species leads to stronger binding. Additionally, analysis of the partial density of states (PDOS) diagram indicates that the overlap between the 2p orbital of CO* and the d orbital on the Ni(111) surface is greatest, and this overlap decreases as Co content increases. This observation is aligned with electron transfer results. Moreover, crystal orbital overlap population (COOP) can provide a more intuitive approach for obtaining bonding and antibonding states to evaluate bonding strength (Figs. S6 and S7). As shown in Fig. S6, below the Fermi level, the interaction orbital between C and the surface is mainly a bonding orbital. Moreover, we integrate the orbitals below the Fermi level to show the bond strength. It is find that the integral value of Ni-C decreases in order of Ni(111), Ni3Co(111), NiCo3(111), and that of Co-C decreases in order of Ni3Co(111), NiCo3(111), and Co(111). In brief, the adsorption energy of intermediates is mainly due to the electron donating ability of the surface. For Co-doped Ni catalysts, the ability to donate electrons is linearly related to the content of Co. Besides, we analyze the C-O bond strength of CO* adsorbed on each surface (Fig. S7). It is evident that the C-O bond strength is significantly higher than the C* to surface bond strength. This suggests that the dissociation of CO* is more likely to occur compared to the cleavage reaction of the C-O bond. Consequently, it can be predicted that the Boudouard reaction (CO* + CO* → C* + CO2) is not easily favored in the DRM reaction process. 3.2 Energy span analysis It is widely accepted that the reaction rate during a catalytic reaction is constant and determined by the maximum reaction rate [49–51]. From a reaction free energy perspective, the energy differences between TDTS and TDI express the rate. This rate is mainly determined by the difference between the maximum reaction transition state free energy and the minimum adsorbates free energy. Based on the above findings, the adsorption energy of intermediate species becomes linear after doping with Co. Therefore, we have neglected the comparison of NiCo3(111) and only focus on investigating the surfaces of Ni(111), Ni3Co(111), and Co(111) to reveal the free energy landscape of DRM on different Ni/Co ratio surfaces. The DRM reaction is generally a complex reaction, and energy span analysis can consider multiple pathways. However, uncertainty may arise for competitive reaction analysis, and thus, the model needs to be simplified, reaction network considered in the current work Based on previous analysis [39], we investigate specific pathways for the formation of H2 gas via CH4 cracking, and CO gas via CO2 decomposition, C oxidation, CHO decomposition, respectively. The corresponding reaction energy barrier and reaction enthalpy (excluding zero-point energy correction) are shown in Tables S3 [52]. The corresponding free energy of reaction enthalpies and activation energies are shown in Tables S4–6, corresponding to surface temperature ranges of 800–1200 K, the effect of increasing temperature by 200 K. The reaction trends of Ni(111), Ni3Co(111) and Co(111) are investigated in terms of free energy landscapes at 1000 K including TDI and TDTS, as shown in Fig. 4 . In general, the free energy landscapes assume a spectrum of continuous rather than simultaneous. Experiments show that the CO2 activation temperature is lower than that of CH4 [53]. For this reason, CO2 activation is the first step of the DRM reaction. This step has an activation energy of 2.52 eV on Ni(111), 2.15 eV on Co(111), and 2.45 eV on Ni3Co(111), respectively. Obviously, the free energy of CO2 activation decreases with an increase in Co content. Moreover, CO2 as the sole source of oxygen can provide more oxygen species. Thereafter, decomposition of CH4 to CH is thermodynamically favorable. CH4 decomposition with a barrier of 2.55 eV on Ni(111), 2.67 eV on Co(111), and 2.58 eV on Ni3Co(111), respectively. Indicating that the increase of Co content will slow down the activation rate of CH4. From the experimental results, the activation energy for CH4 activation on the Ni catalysts is approximately between 0.92 eV and 1.22 eV at around 800 K [54]. According to the Wulff construction, the activation energy for the (111) surface is estimated to be around 0.6–0.7 of the total activation energy [55]. Our calculated data, as shown in Table S1, is 2.25 eV, indicating a discrepancy of approximately 0.2 eV compared to the experimental values. Then the dehydrogenation reaction will continue with a small reaction energy barrier except for CH* decomposition, with a barrier of 1.69 eV on Ni(111), 1.78 eV on Co(111), and 1.73 eV on Ni3Co(111), respectively. Specially, due to CH* decomposition being the main source of carbon, this indicates that increasing the Co content can suppress the rate of carbon deposition. While for CH* oxidation, with a barrier of 2.18 eV on Ni(111), 1.54 eV on Co(111), and 1.46 eV on Ni3Co(111), respectively. Obviously, doping Co makes the oxidation barrier of CH* lower than that of CH* direct decomposition. This leads to two paths to producing CO: C-O (CH4 to C*, and C* coupling with O*) and CH-O (CH4 to CH*, CH* coupling with O* to CHO*, and CHO* decomposition to CO*). Overall, the Ea in order of Co(111) < Ni3Co(111) < Ni(111) for CO2 activation, suggesting that Co doping facilitates carbon deposition removal. Since CO2 activation primarily produces oxygen in DRM, while carbon deposition is mainly removed through oxidation reactions. In contrast, the Ea in order of Ni(111) < Ni3Co(111) < Co(111) for CH4 dissociation, indicating that Co doping reduces the rate of CH4 dissociation. As CH4 dissociation is the rate-limiting reaction, Co doping decreases the overall reaction rate. Notably, carbon deposition primarily occurs through CH* dissociation, the order of Ea for CH* dissociation aligns with that of CH4 dissociation, further indicating the doping of Co makes CH* dissociation difficult, thereby reducing carbon deposition. Interestingly, the order of CH* oxidation energy barriers is Ni3Co(111) < Co(111) < Ni(111), suggesting that the synergistic effect of Ni-Co can enhance the selectivity of the CH-O path higher than that of the CHC path, that is, the selectivity of producing C* is lower than that of CO*. Because the CH-O path has no path of C* formation in the reaction process, increasing the selectivity of CH-O can reduce the possibility of carbon deposition. To further inspect these aspects, we investigate these trends in more detail through an analysis of the experiment temperature. To evaluate the predominant reaction of the DRM reaction at different temperatures, we perform total energy span TOF for each pathway, considering temperature as a variable, as shown in Fig. 5 . Temperature change is mainly used to observe the change in free energy caused by the entropy change of intermediates. Due to the fact that the DRM reaction is a high temperature reaction, the simulation temperature range is set to 800–1200 K, which is consistent with the experimental temperature [56]. Energy span is used to evaluate the overall reaction TOF, calculated by the Arrhenius equation, as shown in Eq. (1). The trend of increasing temperature is associated with a clear rise in TOF values. Specifically, the TOF value of the CH-O pathway is larger than that of CH-C pathway. In addition, at low temperatures (800 K), the reaction rate of Co(111) is 1 to 2 orders of magnitude higher than that of Ni(111) and Ni3Co(111). With the reaction temperature increases, the reaction rates of Ni(111) and Ni3Co(111) approach the same order of magnitude as Co(111). In particular, after 1200 K, the reaction rates of Ni(111) and Ni3Co(111) are significantly higher than that of Co(111). These aspects can be better appreciated by means of a TOF controlling degree analysis. To investigate the selectivity of the DRM reaction, we conduct TDTS and TDI measurements to calculate the TOF degrees, as shown in Fig. 6 . At lower temperatures (800 K), Ni3Co(111) and Ni(111) share similar transition states and intermediate states, except for varying degree proportions. However, the TDTS for Co(111) is CH3-H. These findings suggest that at low temperatures, CO2 activation is the most challenging pathway along the most favorable pathway for Ni3Co(111) and Ni(111), while for Co(111) is easier to occur to CH4 dissociation, these leads to a higher abundance of oxygen species on the Co(111) surface. Upon raising temperatures over 1000 K, the degree of CH3-H presence increases, replacing CO-O as the dominant TDTS and thereby identifying CH3-H as the limiting step on all the surface. Due to the lower energy barrier of CH4 dissociation on Ni(111), the TOF value shows increases continuously. Notably, the value of the TOF degree of C-O on the Ni(111) surface is increasing with the temperature arise, since this reaction is considered the main process for carbon removal, it means that as the temperature increases, removing carbon becomes increasingly challenging for Ni(111). Additionally, this value is much higher for the Co(111) surface than for the Ni3Co(111) surface. Moreover, based on TDI and TDTS values, it can be inferred that the CH-C and CH-O pathways have comparable values for the same surface. Similarly, the TOF values indicate that these two pathways exhibit similar reactivity on the same surface. This suggests that both pathways compete with each other during the reaction process and may occur simultaneously. Consequently, doping Co in the Ni(111) surface reduces the CO2 activation energy, which increases the coverage of O on the surface, increases the probability of combining with C. Furthermore, doping Co increasing the energy barrier for CH dissociation leads to a decrease in carbon deposition. To further study the influence of surface coverage on reaction activity with temperature change, it is necessary to utilize microkinetic modeling to distinguish the catalytic activity of the catalysts. 3.3 Microkinetic simulations The microkinetic model is used to study the kinetic limitations imposed by competitive reaction steps, surface gas dynamics, and coverage restrictions. Based on previous research and experiments, it is shown that the formation of water is inevitable in the DRM reaction process [54]. Thus, the turn over frequency (TOF s − 1) rate of different surfaces is investigated, including all the reaction paths for the formation of CO, H2, and H2O, respectively. The kinetic model used in our calculation considers the reactant gas input ratio of CH4:CO2 =1 and the gas concentration of products (H2) is 10% of the CH4 conversion. All results are based on the steady-state surface concentration. In Fig. 7 , the TOF rates are presented against temperature for the three surfaces studied. In general, increasing temperature results in an increase in reaction rate. On the Ni(111) surface, the formation rates of CO and H2O rise with increasing temperature. Notably, the rate of CO generation is significantly higher than that of H2O. At around 880 K, the generation of H2 is detected, and its rate is comparable to that of CO, although it is slightly lower at temperatures below 1000 K. These results are similar to those of Guharoy et al. on Ni2P(0001) [57]. On the surface of Co(111), at the initial stage (800 K), the formation rates of CO and H2O are close and one order of magnitude higher than those on the surface of Ni(111). With the increase in temperature, the formation of H2 is detected at around 1090 K. This is mainly due to the high H2O generation rate, which makes the surface H* mainly combine with O* to form OH*, thus, the H2 generation rate is negative before 1090 K. With the decrease in H2O formation rate, the H2 formation rate gradually increases. On the Ni3Co(111) surface, the reaction rate of CO is closer to that of Co(111) in the initial stage, and the temperature of H2 generation is closer to the surface of Ni(111). In sum, the reaction rates increase in order Ni(111), Ni3Co(111), and Co(111) at lower temperatures, while the trend is opposite at high reaction temperatures. Combined with the above analysis, it suggest that the main reaction is CO2 activation at low temperatures, while an increase in temperature, the main reaction becomes CH3-H. Together, these indicate that the Co site is the main CO2 activation site at low temperatures and the Ni site is the main active site of CH4 dissociation. However, it is still not possible to determine the main path of CO on each surface by the reaction rate of CO formation. To point out the influence of the path of CO formation on the reaction rates, the reactant formation rates of different paths on each surface are investigated, as shown in Fig. S11. On the Co(111) surface, at the low temperature stage, the formation rates of CO in the CH-O path and the CH-C path are consistent. As the temperature increases, the formation rates of CO in the CH-C path approach equilibrium until 1100 K, while the formation rates of CO in the CH-O path exhibit an exponential upward trend, becoming nearly one order of magnitude higher than those in the CH-C path at 1300 K. The reaction rates of the CH-O path remain the same as the total reaction rate across the entire temperature range. Similarly, on the Ni3Co(111) surface, the formation rates of CO in the CH-O path are a little higher than those in the CH-C path. On the Ni(111) surface, the CH-O path is dominant at low temperatures, while the CH-C path becomes more significant as the temperature increases. Furthermore, the temperature of H2 generation in the CH-C path is higher than that in the CH-O path. As the H2 formation rates increase, the CO formation rates in the CH-C path gradually surpass those in the CH-O path at around 1050 K. Therefore, the CH-O path is the primary pathway on the Co(111) and Ni3Co(111) surfaces. However, on the Ni(111) surface, the CH-O path serves as the initial path, which is later replaced by the CH-C path at elevated temperatures. These results are similar to the trend of energy span predicted by TOF, except for the Ni(111) surface. The results of energy span tend to be the competition between CH-O and CH-C at low temperatures, which is mainly because microkinetic modeling considers the limitation of surface coverage on kinetics, while energy span tends to the maximum reaction rate. In order to obtain a more in-depth understanding of the reaction kinetics, we conduct a coverage analysis on the steady-state as a function of temperature, as illustrated in Fig. 8 . It is well established that the concentration of species on the surface reaches a steady-state, the reaction reaches equilibrium, and the transient advantages of multiple species have a significant impact on the reaction rate [58]. Therefore, we focus our investigation on the change in coverage of the main species with temperature. On the Ni(111) surfaces, we observe that O* represents the most abundant species on the surface initially, with a coverage of around 0.9 monolayer (ML) between 800 K and 900 K. However, as the temperature increased, the coverage of O* dropped sharply, and the surface coverage quickly shifted towards CO* and CH*. Additionally, at around 900 K, the coverage ratio of C* increased, indicating that the reaction rate of CH4 dissociation increased at around 900 K. This phenomenon can be attributed to the fact that the activation process of CO2 occurs first in the reaction, with CH4 activation becoming dominant as temperatures rise. Therefore, the reaction path shifted towards CH4 dissociation, resulting in a decrease in O* coverage and an increase in CO* and CH* coverage. On the Co(111) surface, we observe that O* dominated as the main surface species throughout the entire temperature range. With the increase in temperature, the surface concentration of O* gradually increased, and when the temperature reached 1100 K, the surface coverage reached around 1 ML, which also easily poisoned the surface and caused the reaction rate to drop sharply. On the contrary, the surface concentration of C* is close to 0 ML, which makes it difficult to generate carbon deposits. This is consistent with the Uemiya et al. experimental results [59]. On the Ni3Co(111) surface, at the initial stage, the surface coverage of major species is similar to that of Co(111). Specifically, as the temperature increased over 900 K, the surface coverage of CO* decline sharply, accompanied by an increase in the coverage of O*. Notably, the surface concentration of O* is less than 1 ML, and the concentration of C* tends to be 0 ML. In light of above TOF analysis, we observe that at the initial stage, the reaction pathway involve in the activation of CO2 and CH4 decomposition reactions is slow. Additionally, H2O is generate through the reaction of H* with OH*. The surface coverage of O* decreases due to its reaction with H*, which can be represented as O* + H* → OH*. Therefore, the production of H2O makes the production rate of H2 negative, especially when the production rate of H2O is close to that of CO. It can be seen that as the temperature increase, the formation rate of CO outpace that of H2O, leading to a decrease in O* consumption, which result in an increase in O* surface coverage. When temperatures exceed 1100 K, the surface coverage of major species is similar to that of Ni(111), in terms of product rate, the two surface trends are similar. To sum up, Combine with the formation rate of the main products, it shows that at the initial stage of the Ni(111) surface, due to the low formation rate of H2O, there are a large number of O* species on the surface that do not participate in the reaction. With the increase in temperature, the CH4 dissociation reaction develops into the main reaction, which makes the surface begin to react with C* and O* to form CO*, which makes the surface coverage of CO* increase and the surface coverage of O* decrease sharply. It is worth noting that for Ni(111) surfaces, the coverage of C* species is larger than that of Co(111) surfaces, which is mainly due to the decomposition reaction of CH on Ni(111) surfaces. 3.4 Deactivation mechanism of catalysis Previous analysis reveal that deactivation in Ni is primarily due to C-C coupling [24]. To investigate the deactivation mechanism for different Ni/Co ratios, we investigate the long-term C-C coupling mechanism on Ni(111) and Ni3Co(111) surfaces, as well as the impact of prolonged reactions on Co(111). To achieve a more accurate simulation, we extended the reaction cycle time to 1000 h, exceeding the maximum duration of carbon deposition production (850 h) [60]. To investigate the mechanism of carbon accumulation on the surface, we investigate the variation in surface coverage over time at 1000 K, as shown in Fig. S12. Initially, the surface coverage changes rapidly but eventually stabilizes. On the Ni(111) surface, the presence of O* leads to a decrease in C* coverage. As the reaction progresses, the O* concentration declines, and CC* appears on the surface after 50 h. The surface coverage of CC* gradually increases while O* decreases, indicating continuous increase in CC* concentration. On the other hand, the Ni3Co(111) surface initially shows few adsorbed C* but quickly undergoes transformation into CO* with the increase in O* concentration. Notably, CC* detection is absent even after 1000 h on the Ni3Co(111) surface. The Co(111) surface predominantly exhibits O* species. Further investigation on the temperature dependency of surface coverage is represented in Fig. S13. On the Ni(111) surface, the surface coverage of CC* gradually rises with increasing temperature, resulting in surface poisoning. Conversely, on the Ni3Co(111) surface, the surface coverage of CC* starts to increase gradually around 1200 K. For the Co(111) surface, the surface coverage of O* reaches 1 ML after 1100 K, which indicates surface poisoning due to O* with prolong reaction time. Considering surface deactivation, the reaction rates significantly decrease on all surfaces, as depicted in Fig. 9 . On the Ni(111) surface, the reaction rate consistently decreases after 1100 K. When considering the formation rate of reactants, the maximum reaction rate decreases by two orders of magnitude after carbon deposition. On the Ni3Co(111) surface, the reaction rate only decreases by one order of magnitude and exhibits a decline after 1200 K. For the Co(111) surface, there is no change in the reaction rate before 1000 K. However, after 1000 K, the rate of product formation decreases due to O* deactivation. The temperature at which the reaction rate decreases aligns with the appearance of CC* and O* poisoning on the surface, indicating that carbon deposition is the main cause for Ni(111) deactivation, while O* poisoning contributes to Co(111) deactivation. On the Ni3Co(111) surface, the presence of Co increases the surface coverage of O*, facilitating the combination of surface C* and O* and reducing the formation rate of CC*, thereby improving coking resistance. In sum, based on the previous analysis, the reaction rate increases with temperature on all surfaces, considering the reaction duration and the impact of C-C coupling. It is evident that on the Ni(111) surface, at a temperature of 1000 K, carbon deposition begins after 10 h, and the reaction rate starts to decrease at temperatures exceeding 1200 K, indicating that the suitable reaction temperature range for the Ni(111) surface is between 1000 and 1100 K. On the Ni3Co(111) surface, due to the synergistic effect of Ni-Co, the suitable reaction temperature range is between 1000 and 1200 K; carbon deposition begins at temperatures exceeding 1200 K. Additionally, at around 1000 K, the Ni3Co(111) surface is at a critical point for the C* and O* reactions, where the produced C* can react with O*, resulting in less carbon deposition. As for the Co(111) surface, prolonged reaction times lead to surface deactivation due to an increase in O* coverage, consistent with experimental results [61]. Therefore, it suggests that in the DRM reaction, by adjusting the surface coverage of O* on the Ni(111) surface, carbon deposition can be reduced. 3.5 Insights into future Ni-based catalyst design Combine with the aforementioned research, we have elucidated the activity and deactivation mechanism of Ni catalysts for the DRM reaction. Temperature significantly impacts the activity of Ni catalysts. Higher temperatures enhance catalyst activity but also accelerate the C-C reaction rate, leading to the formation of surface carbon, which continues to accumulate during the reaction. However, with a small amount of Co doping, the temperature at which CC* forms increases. This allows for long-term operation at experimental temperatures without carbon deposition, while maintaining the activity of the Ni catalyst at a similar level. The main reason for this improvement is that Co doping enhances the concentration of O* on the catalyst surface. For the DRM reaction, the surface coverage of O* mainly comes from CO2. Thus, we investigate the catalyst mechanism on the Ni(111) surface by varying the concentration of CO2. Fig. 10 displays the temperature-dependent TOF diagram of the Ni(111) surface under different CO2 concentrations. It can be seen that when CH4/CO2 = 2, the surface reaction activity of Ni(111) is lower by one magnitude than that of Co-doped, but there is no obvious tendency to decline. When CH4/CO2 = 3, the generation rate of H2 is negative due to the high generation rate of H2O, and the production rate of CO slightly declines compared to other CO2 ratios. Furthermore, we investigate the changes in surface coverage by altering the concentration of CO2 (Figs. S14 and S15). Obviously, the surface coverage of O* is mainly influenced by the concentration of CO2. Under the reaction conditions of CH4:CO2 = 1:2, no adsorb CC* is observed before 1150 K. Under the reaction conditions of CH4:CO2 = 1:3, although CC* does not appear during the reaction, the surface becomes predominantly occupied by O*, resulting in poisoning of the surface and a lower reactant generation rate. It is noteworthy that the increase in CO2 feed rate on the Ni(111) surface does not affect the concentration of surface CO*. Hence, it can be inferred that the decrease in CC* primarily stems from the occupation of surface O* coverage, leading to a decline in surface C* concentration and subsequent reduction in surface carbon deposition. Therefore, the surface coverage of O* can be adjusted by appropriately adjusting the ratio of CH4 to CO2, but high CO2 concentrations can cause surface O poisoning, thereby affecting the progress of the reaction. Although the proportion of synthesis gas will change, it has a wider proportion of synthesis gas to meet the industrial demand [62], which provide valuable guidance for rational design of effective DRM catalysts 4 Conclusions The present study is primarily focused on investigating how the catalytic performance of Ni-based catalysts in the DRM reaction is influenced by the addition of Co dopants and reaction condition. Specifically, employing DFT calculations, we have constructed the energy span and provided inputs for microkinetic modeling to perform a systematic analysis of both the activity and carbon deposition pathways in the reaction conditions. The main conclusions are as follows: (1) The adsorption energies of primary adsorbates on the Ni/Co surfaces exhibit a linear correlation that is intimately related to the adsorbates and surface electronic interactions. More specifically, Co doping is known to preferentially stabilize O-containing species, whereas Ni enhances CHx adsorption. Consequently, tuning the Ni/Co ratio can be employed as an effective strategy to modulate the stability of adsorbates and thereby control DRM reaction pathways. (2) In terms of reaction kinetics, the deactivation mechanisms of Ni(111) and Co(111) on the catalyst surfaces exhibit different characteristics. Specifically, the surface carbon concentration of CC* plays a dominant role in the deactivation of Ni at increasing temperatures, while the primary reason for Co deactivation is attributed to surface O* poisoning induced by prolonged reaction times. The synergistic effect between Ni and Co results in reduced surface carbon sites on the Ni/Co catalyst, but excessive dopant concentrations may induce surface O* poisoning. Thus, optimizing the doping ratio is crucial to balance the benefits and risks of Ni-Co alloy catalysts for dry reforming of methane application. (3) Based on the Ni-Co synergy regulation for carbon deposition, modulating the CH4/CO2 inlet ratio has been found to effectively regulate the surface O* concentration. Through systematic investigation, it is discovered that a 1:2 CH4/CO2 ratio achieved the highest TOF of the reaction products. Our proposed methodology can provide valuable guidance for the optimization of Ni-based catalysts, leading to improved catalytic performance and stability. This innovative finding presents a new avenue for addressing the long-standing challenge of carbon deposition on Ni catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The dry reforming of methane plays a vital role in carbon recycling. However, despite their high activity, Ni catalysts are susceptible to deactivation caused by the deposition of carbon. Co-doped Ni catalysts can address this issue, but the doping ratio has obvious effect on the activity. In this study, we utilized density functional theory calculations and microkinetic model simulations to gain insight into how Co doping affects both carbon deposition resistance and Ni catalytic activity. By analyzing the reaction mechanism, we discovered that the concentration of surface O* significantly influences the deactivation of carbon deposition on the surface of Ni-based catalysts. An appropriate concentration of O* can reduce the occupation of CC* sites, while excessive O* results in surface poisoning and reduced H2 production rates. We propose that the anti-carbon deposition performance of Ni catalysts can be improved by modulating the CH4/CO2 inlet ratio appropriately. Our findings provide valuable guidance for rational design of effective DRM catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Promotion of activity and stability mechanisms of adjusting the Co ratio in nickel-based catalysts for dry reforming of methane reaction
